review_title: Pfizer is a company that rewards based on talent
pros: Judged solely on performance and not on race, gender or any other quality. Best of the best medicines to market. Strong inclusivity culture. The company truly cares for the patients it serves. Highly professional in every area of the company.
cons: Processes change frequently so you are always learning new software and metrics and there is the "flavor of the year" motivational tactic, which can be tiresome. There is literally a metric for every single thing that can be measured and, depending on your manager, you can be micromanaged or given freedom to do your job. The industry as a whole is difficult to maneuver through depending on the area you work in based on access to physicians.

pros:
- Pay is ok, about on par with the other big pharmas. Benefits are pretty good. 401k matching is generous. PTO policy is flexible 
- Healthcare benefits are decent. Stock vesting schedule is very long. 
- Job is great if you are a "box -checker", or on the marketing side of the house
cons:
- I've worked at a lot of large companies, but the culture within the technology group here is unlike anything I've ever seen. Toxic, treating employees like they're nothing...it's just awful. Leadership is tone deaf to the feedback and sentiment of the broader working population. More broadly speaking, Digital / tech are viewed as second class citizens within the broader company. People are outright rude and mean. 
- Employees are reluctant to share ideas because there is the constant stealing and rebranding of work. Motivation is of course low when employees see this - why work hard when you're going to receive 0 credit for the effort put forward?
- Not a single person within the org cares about career development. There is no career progression or pathway outlined whatsoever. Progress only happens when people change roles, with most of them looking to leave Digital.
- Technology is seen as a cost and a burden, rather than an innovation tool. 
- Leadership is super tactical and constantly managing to budgets and headcount. The constant reorgs result in a lot of lay offs and shuffling. 
- There's a huge disconnect between ELT messaging and the SVP/VP level management. Executive leadership touts change and flexibility, while SVPs/VPs are old-school and rigid in terms of their approach
- Innovation is tough of course because of the industry regulations. Legal and compliance are a part of the problem, but the org fails to look elsewhere at the outdated, antiquated, and time-consuming processes that have been put in place yrs ago and no one has thought to change.

review_title: Agile Leadership Behaviors are words here, not actions
pros: It’s an amazing company that claims to value people and achieve breakthroughs in short periods of time. The CEO and direct higher level leaders reporting to him are in alignment. Those below that level - not so much.
cons:
Agility is being “rolled out” by a huge vendor company who stood it up for them. The vendor is top notch, but the agile program is definitely “vendorized” with a specific structure and layers of steps and PowerPoints . The Pfizer leaders taking over the agile program, not so awesome. 
They are open to future coaches changing the structured program accordingly so this is a huge plus. 

The Agile Leaderships’ actions clearly demonstrate that some of them are “gods” and people must adjust their behaviors to align to THEIR preferences. There is no level playing field for agility to grow, and no chance to form, norm, storm etc…. One mistake leads to high scrutiny. then two and 3 mistakes, and then you are placed on a termination plan 3-4 weeks after joining. Scary! 

Middle leadership also appears to be scared of their own talent they hire, and does not know what behaviors come into play with agile leaders or today’s ways of working. They are not willing to have meaningful conversations or allow for mistakes that help people to grow.

review_title: Great culture, yet company is behind the times
pros: Pfizer has a great culture with strong benefits and some truly authentic colleagues who care about you. Strong passion for changing the world that gives a lot of motivation for your work. Most colleagues are very friendly and willing to mentor.
cons: Top leadership is not transparent. Although it’s advertised you can climb up in the company, many leaders tend to value years spent with the Pfizer over a colleague’s performance reviews/reputation/new ideas. It’s common to not feel recognized and valued depending on which part of the company you work for. More senior colleagues tend to get new role and promotional opportunities than those more junior, it’s hard to find advancement and a leader willing to listen if you haven’t worked at Pfizer for 10+ years

job_title: Data Science Associate in New York, NY
pros: CEO and leadership has an incredible commitment to D&I anti-racist initiatives and has a blooming Global Black Community CRG and Latino CRG (I’m Latino myself) and this has made creating and expanding a network possible even while working remote the past year. Opportunities for advancement and internal hiring is constant and available. Opportunities to grow are there IF you really shine and are excellent. You also need to be known, build a brand, and have a cereer mentor AND sponsor. Otherwise promotions are hard to come by. Yearly education benefits are available as well. Super incredible work life balance (not like banks or consultant companies) and Pfizer is very flexible. Get most of your work done at night? Then take the day to do other stuff. Meetings with China at midnight? Sleep in until whenever the next day. Pay is decent, not the bottom of the curve not not like banking/consultant level either and our engineers get paid similar to the likes of other tech companies. But it’s worth it for the benefits, the leadership, flexibility to have a whole life outside of work. Also crazy maternal and paternal leave (6-9months off with pay). It’s a company filled with lovely, committed, & intelligent colleagues who bring A LOT of value to Pfizer’s culture and shape the core essence of Pfizer’s new brand.
cons: It’s not like other companies where there is a specific promotion timeline, to move up in pay grade levels you usually have to apply internally for another position at a higher grade level. Other option is promotion within your current role ... but even then it’s never certain and entirely depends on your performance (has to be above and beyond) as well as who “has your back” when it comes to discussing your compensation.

job_title: Human Resources Manager in Peapack, NJ
pros: Benefits are top-notch, super flexible environment
cons: Pfizer is an amazing company to work for if you are able to keep up with the demands of the job AND you must be able to survive the constant change. To HR you are just a number so when it comes to re-structure upper management will always be protected and lower management will always be at risk. They will tell you they need to eliminate repetition and so mana layers of the organization when in fact they add "new layers" and "new positions" to accommodate and promote those within the circle of the upper management. Too much favoritism. They talk about minorities and females in the workplace but yet they are very few in upper management roles. If you are looking for just a job this is the place to be.
